description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please **For TMT+:** Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
**Output 1: the newly developed entrepreneurship curriculum that is gender sensitive, open to host community & refugee youth and that provides trainees with practical entrpereneurship tools to start their own business is implemented within the VTC of Erbil**
The output is partly realised. During consultations with project partners, we decided to not develop a completely new entrepreneurship curriculum but to enrich the already developed "I am an Entrepreneur" curriculum of UNESCO. Reason for this is that this curriculum is developed in 2018 but has only seen one pilot in the VTC of Erbil. The curriculum is in line with the recently endorsed TVQF (endorsed in 2021) of Iraq. Building further on this curriculum is therefore most logical. The enrichment proces focussed on 1) making the curriculum more practical, 2) adding more attention to entrepreneurial attidues, 3) giving attention to Mental Health and Psycho-social support elements. One big addition to the project proposal is that - in consultation with MoLSA - the newly enriched curriculum will not only be implemented in the VTC of Erbil, but in all 8 VTCs throughout the Kurdistan region. The implementation of the curriculum is planned for 2022 and has not yet taken place.
**Output 2: Teaching staff of VTC Erbil and respresentatives of the other five VTCs apply their newly acquired skills and knowledge in their teaching **14 teachers have been trained in the TMT+ training sessions conducted in 2021. They have not yet been able to apply these newly acquired skills and knowledge since the implementation of the entrepreneurship course is planned in 2022. These teachers have also not been able to teach other subjects in which they could apply their newly acquired skills as there has been too little financing for TVET in 2021 (which caused a lack of students).
**Output 3: The VTC in Erbil established strong and structural relationships with local private sector organisations: MSMEs, finance institutes, markets, mentors and experts **Even though the teachers cooperated with succesful entrepreneurs during the curriculum development workshops, this output deserves attention during the next project phase. During the Jordan learning exchange, the VTC coaches decided they will do personal outreach to local entrepreneurs for the mentorship programme. Such outreach is a first step in establishing more structural relationships with private sector organisations. The VTCs currently have very limited relationships with the private sector. Cordaid will focus on connection to finance institutes and markets during the next project phase.
**Output 4: Integration of refugee youth in formal TVET education and private sector **Consultations between CINOP and UNHCR in Iraq resulted in a mutual agreement that UNHCR will assist us in reaching the most vulnerable refugees with entrepreneurship aspirations before the start of the course in 2022. Their network and trust among the refugee community is needed for outreach activities to stimulate enrolment in the course. MoLSA has officially opened the opportunity for refugees to participate in the VTCs, so no legal barriers are there. Teaching staff of the VTCs are trained in MHPSS topics in order to deal with cultural differences and trauma in the classroom. The implementation of the entrepreneurship course -with mixed classes of host community and refugee youth- will serve as a pilot to monitor the integration of refugee youth in the formal TVET system.
​

title.narrative: I. Education system is of good quality, relevant and accessible
I.E.1. Number of (knowledge) institutions that perform better

description.narrative: Write here the definition of a better performance

comment.narrative: 21-01-2022: In the proposal phase of this project, we agreed to work with all Vocational Training Centres in the Kurdistan region under the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs. At the time of proposal writing, there were only 6 VTCs. However, during the last year there were two new VTCs established under MoLSA. The first one was the -already existing and running- Swedish Academy in Erbil who is now formally a MoLSA VTC. The second one is the recently opened VTC in Halabja. During the first activities of the project, the initial 6 VTCs participated. From September 2021 onwards, there were 2 training sessions conducted in which all 8 VTCs participated. All project partners agreed of the importance of including the newest VTC members in order to ensure the benefits of the TMT+ project are open to all VTCs. The performance of the VTCs have improved in the topics of: - Teaching staff gained knowledge on MHPSS & gender awareness in education - Entrepreneurship curricula enriched - Teaching staff gained knowledge on inclusive entrepreneurship education for refugees/IDPs - Teaching staff and manager of the VTCs gained inspiration on future VTC plans due to a learning-exchange with Jordanian organisations

title.narrative: I.E.4. Number of revised/newly developed curricula in NL and/or Southern partner organisation that integrate research results

comment.narrative: 21-01-2022: The aim of project partners was to develop an entrepreneurship course that was demand-driven and inclusive to all. After initial consultations with Dr. Arif (deputy general of MoLSA), an adaptation in the initial plan was made. Instead of developing a completely new curriculum, we worked together with UNESCO to strengthen and enrich their entrepreneurship curriculum. In 2018, UNESCO developed the "I am an Entrepreneur" curriculum for all MoLSA training centres (in KR-I as well as Central Iraq). This curriculum was in line with the Technical Vocational Qualification Framework (TVQF) which was also developed by UNESCO and which is endorsed in 2021. In order to build further upon the work of UNESCO, CINOP worked together with their experts in order to further strengthen the existing curriculum. The main additions made is the incorporation of MHPSS elements and more practical learning objectives & a focus on entrepreneurial attitudes In the next phase of the TMT+ project, this curriculum will be piloted in all 8 VTCs.

title.narrative: II.P.7. Number of Dutch training education organisations that have improved their training methods

comment.narrative: 21-01-2022: CINOP has improved their training on inclusive education for refugees. CINOP has the ECIO organisation in-house, this is the Expertise Centre of Inclusive Education (Expertise Centrum Inclusief Onderwijs) who work with Dutch vocational and higher education institutes in providing more inclusive education. For the TMT+ QEfR project in Iraq, the workshop on 'persona building and experiencing inclusivity' which was developed for the Dutch market was contextualised and implemented in a workshop for the VTCs. CINOP is able to further contextualise this workshop to other regions. The consul of the Netherlands in Erbil - Hans Akerboom - opened the workshop on persona's and inclusive entrepreneurship education. | 21-01-2022: CINOP has improved their training on inclusive education for refugees. CINOP is able to further contextualise this workshop to other regions. title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 21-01-2022: 13 out of 14 participants stated they found the information during the workshops 'very useful', one participants stated the workshops were 'somewhat useful'. The challenge in the next phase of the project is to monitor how the participants implement the newly acquired knowledge and skills in their work (during the implementation of the entrepreneurship course). After the final module of the TMT+ is offered to the teaching staff, a final survey is shared in which participants are asked about their newly acquired knowledge and skills, this will give a better image of the effectiveness of the training sessions.

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: 21-01-2022: For the female participants in the workshops, extra logistical measures are taken. All training workshops took place in Erbil. Erbil was also the starting and ending point for the Jordan learning trip. Women in Kurdistan are only allowed to travel during day light. We ensured that they were able to travel to Erbil and stay in a hotel 1 day before the start of each workshop and 1 day after the end of each workshop. This allowed them to participate.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: public vocational training centres

21-01-2022: In this stage of the project, the 8 VTCs of MoLSA KR-I (amongst which the 6 traditional ones and the 2 newest members) are strengthened through the group training sessions conducted in the TMT+ project. It are the entrepreneurship teachers who participate in all training sessions, so the institutes are especially strengthened in the quality and inclusiveness of their entrepreneurship education.

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 21-01-2022: Not yet applicable, final satisfaction survey to be distributed after the final TMT+ workshop since the workshops can be seen as different modules.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 21-01-2022: Not yet applicable. Since the enriched entrepreneurship course (as well as the former "I am an Entrepreneur" course of UNESCO) have never been taught in the VTCs, the entrepreneurship coaches have not been able to put their new knowledge and skills into practice. In the next phase of the project (in 2022), the first batches of students will start.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 21-01-2022: Up until now, 14 participants have participated in the TMT+ workshops. However, more workshops are planned in 2022 and the workshops are seen as a complete package. So succesful completion of the TMT+ workshops cannot be evaluated at this moment. We are greatly challenged by the number of females participating in the workshops. There are several reasons for this: - MoLSA directorate has employed only 4 female trainers to provide entrepreneurship training in the VTCs (of which 2 participated in the workshops) - The other 2 female trainers are on maternity leave, which can take up to a year in Kurdistan CINOP, Cordaid and MoLSA are currently discussing together how the number of female entrepreneurship teachers can be increased. Especially because female students can benefit greatly from female role models when the entrepreneurship course is implemented next year. The main idea currently is to bring female entrepreneurs to the classroom for guest lecturing, but this idea needs further research.

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value:
In March 2021, fifteen entrepreneurship coaches of the Vocational Training Centres of MoLSA met each other in the Swedish Academy in Erbil. They travelled from various governates including Sulimania, Erbil, Dohuk, Soran and Garmyan to attend a training on Mental Health and Psycho-social Support (MHPSS) and gender awareness in educational settings.
The aim of the workshop was to strengthen the capacity of coaches of the VTCs to recognize and give attention to mental health and gender equality topics in the classroom. Youth in Iraq are affected by conflict and crisis, and bring these experiences with them when they enter the classroom. Vocational training is still perceived to be ‘a thing for men’, and even though women enrol in vocational training, they often do not apply for vocational jobs. Instead of staying silent about such topics (which are often considered taboo), teachers are inspired to talk about them with their students. Recognition of the mere existence of mental health issues, trauma and gender issues is already a first step in supporting students in their learning process. The teachers will implement these learnings during the implementation phase of the entrepreneurship course. Where the project partners will monitor the application of gender awareness and gender sensitive teaching in the classroom.
Added photo is made during the MHPSS & Gender Awareness training
